docs.lead_paragraph: An overload of conflicting and often alarmist information about vaccinations is leading some medical experts into a new field of research: not the effectiveness and safety of vaccines, which they consider proven, but the public's questions, doubts and fears. ''Just because we're doctors doesn't mean we don't also look at the Internet,'' said Dr. Bruce G. Gellin of Vanderbilt University, staff director of the Vaccine Initiative, a special project of the Infectious Diseases Society of America. Some Web sites about immunization, he said, ''focus to a large degree on concerns about safety that are far more hypothesis than fact.''
docs.abstract: Overload of conflicting and often alarmist information about vaccinations is leading some medical experts into a new field of research: not the effectiveness and safety of vaccines, which they consider proven, but public's questions, doubts and fears; Infectious Diseases Society of America has created initiative, which is using focus groups, surveys and other marketing tools to explain immunization to public; doctors fight backlash over vaccines (M)
docs.snippet: An overload of conflicting and often alarmist information about vaccinations is leading some medical experts into a new field of research: not the effectiveness and safety of vaccines, which they consider proven, but the public's questions, doubts...

docs.lead_paragraph: Almost 30 years ago, researchers discovered that Europeans in Mediterranean countries were less likely to suffer from heart disease than people elsewhere. This better health was attributed to the Mediterranean diet, one low in meat and high in fruits, vegetables, olive oil and wine.
docs.abstract: Dr Jean-Paul Broustet, cardiologist in Bordeaux region of France, recounts three decades of research on health benefits of wine, concluding that cabernet sauvignon made from Bordeaux grapes is best wine to drink for good cardiovascular health and longevity (S)
docs.snippet: Almost 30 years ago, researchers discovered that Europeans in Mediterranean countries were less likely to suffer from heart disease than people elsewhere.    This better health was attributed to the Mediterranean diet, one low in meat and high in...

docs.lead_paragraph: Middle-income blacks, Hispanics and whites have significantly different attitudes toward health care, a new national survey confirms with a range of new statistics. This research raises concern among minority leaders that two separate and unequal systems of care have developed in the United States. The survey was conducted by Morehouse College of Medicine, a predominantly black institution in Atlanta, and the New American Wellness Group, a communications and marketing company that focuses on minority health care issues.

headline.main: Health Care Systems in U.S. Called Separate and Unequal

docs.abstract: New national survey finds that middle-income blacks, Hispanics and whites have significantly different attitudes toward health care; research raises concerns among minority leaders that two separate and unequal systems of care have developed in United States; survey was conducted by Morehouse College of Medicine, predominanlty black institution in Atlanta, and New American Wellness Group, communications and marketing company that focuses on minority health care issues; among findings is that far fewer blacks and Hispanics than whites have a doctor of their own race or ethnicity (M)
docs.snippet: Middle-income blacks, Hispanics and whites have significantly different attitudes toward health care, a new national survey confirms with a range of new statistics. This research raises concern among minority leaders that two separate and unequal...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the seven months since an Australian man received a new hand and forearm in France, he has defied medical dogma. His body has not rejected the graft, and nerves are regenerating faster than his doctors expected. Yet the relationship of the transplant pioneer, Clint Hallam, 48, and the doctors is strained over his lack of further progress. Mr. Hallam is gaining feeling in his new fingers and hand. He has clipped new fingernails, and hair is growing on the forearm below its point of attachment. Mr. Hallam, who said he is a former computer consultant, looks trim and healthy. He also said he was going to a gym at least four hours a day and was taking lessons to resume playing the piano and flying an airplane.

headline.main: 'Role Model' With a Past Clouds Medical Triumph

docs.abstract: Clint Hallam, Australian man who receieved new hand and forearm in France in 1998, is progressing beyond the expectations of his doctors; his body has not rejected graft, and nerves are regenerating faster than expected; but there has been a slowing of progress, which Hallam's doctors say is due to Hallam's failure to follow prescribed supervised physical and occupational therapy; relationship between Hallam and doctors is also strained by fact that it was only at time of surgery that doctors learned that Hallam had lost his hand to a saw while in prison in New Zealand in 1984; Hallam had been convicted of fraud; photos (L)
docs.snippet: In the seven months since an Australian man received a new hand and forearm in France, he has defied medical dogma. His body has not rejected the graft, and nerves are regenerating faster than his doctors expected. Yet the relationship of the...

docs.lead_paragraph: We have all had heartburn now and then, if at no other time, then after consuming a highly acidic or spicy food or when bending over or exercising vigorously soon after eating a full meal. And in most cases, if any treatment was needed, an over-the-counter antacid took care of the temporary discomfort. But for about 15 million Americans, heartburn is not occasional. It is a daily occurrence that, if not treated indefinitely on a daily basis, can develop into something far more serious -- a change in the cells lining the esophagus that may progress into a very serious cancer.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on heartburn and the danger that chronic heartburn, if not treated, may cause cells lining esophagus to change and become cancerous; incidence of esophageal cancer precipitated by chronic heartburn is increasing faster than any other cancer in nation today, and it is incurable in nearly 90 percent of cases; guidelines on dealing with chronic heartburn; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a recent article published in The British Journal of Sports Medicine, a sociologist proposed a theory that could launch a thousand hours of talk-radio discussion. If not for a history of medical myths and a lack of athletic opportunity, it is at least possible, suggested Dr. Ellis Cashmore, a professor at Staffordshire University in Stoke-on-Trent, England, that in all sports that demand skill as opposed to pure brawn, women might have been competing at levels comparable with their male counterparts.

headline.main: Frailty Myth Haunts Women in Sports

docs.abstract: Mary Duffy Essay on impediments to closing performance gap between men and women in athletics, especially lingering view of women as the 'weaker' sex (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In an effort to protect children from damaging ultraviolet rays, three agencies plan to build what they describe as the nation's first intentionally sun-safe playground. The Children's Aid Society, the American Academy of Dermatologists, and Kaboom, a playground safety group, will undertake the project on Friday at the Goodhue Center on Staten Island.
docs.abstract: Three agencies plan to build what they describe as nation's first playground that protects children from ultraviolet rays; Children's Aid Society, American Academy of Dermatologists, and Kaboom, playground safety group, will undertake project at Goodhue Center on Staten Island; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists is now recommending that Jews of Central and Eastern European descent be offered screening to determine whether they are carriers of Canavan disease, an inherited neurological disorder that causes most children with the disease to die before age 10. Symptoms usually appear when children are between 3 and 6 months of age and involve delays in development, poor head control and an enlarged head. As the disease progresses, it causes seizures, severe feeding problems, significant motor delays and often blindness. There is no effective therapy for the disease, which can occur only when both parents are carriers of the recessive Canavan gene.
docs.abstract: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends that Jews of Central and Eastern European descent be offered screening to determine whether they are carriers of Canavan disease, an inherited neurological disorder that causes most children with disease to die before age 10 (S)
